columns.text: In this problem, we have to determine the price of the call option price when the exercise price is the same as in the case of the put option i.e. $\$45$

There are two types of options: Call Option and Put Option. In order to value these options, it is important to understand that in the case of the Call option the option holder has bought the **right of purchasing** the underlying asset at a fixed price in the future.

 Whereas in the case of the Put option the option holder has bought the **right of selling** the underlying asset at a fixed price in future. This fixed price is known as the **exercise price**.

The put-call parity general equation as follows: 

 $$ \text{S + P} = \text{PV(E)} + \text{C}$$

where

$\text{PV(E)}$ is the present value of the Exercise Price,
  
$\text{P}$ is the Put option price, 

$\text{S}$ is the Stock Price,

$\text{r}$ is the Risk-free Rate,

$\text{t}$ is the Time period,  

$\text{C}$ is the Call option price.

The present value can be calculated by using the following formula (in case of continuous compounding):

$$\text{ Present value = Future value $\times e^{-rt}$}$$

where $r$ is the interest rate,

$t$ is the time period

$e$ is the natural exponential function. It is a constant with the approximate value of $2.718$

Let us now identify the given information:


| **Particulars**| **Value**| 
|--|--| 
|Exercise Price (E) |$45 | 
|Put option price (P)|$2.34|
|Stock Price (S)|$48|
|Risk-free rate |3.5%|
|Time period (t)|6 months|

This is the case of continuous compounding.

Now we will find the present value of the exercise price. 

Since the time period is $6$ months and the rate of interest is annual, the semi-annual rate is calculated below. It should be noted that the time period is considered to be $1$. Accordingly,  

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Effective Rate of Interest} &= \frac{3.5}{2} \\[10pt]
&= 1.750\%
\end{aligned}$$

Thus the effective interest rate for the period of six months is $1.75\%$.

Using the formula  in step 4, we will calculate the present value. It is done below:

$$\begin{aligned} 
\text{Present Value} & = \$45 \times e^{-0.0175 \times 1}\\
& = \$45 \times e^{-0.0175}\\
& = \$45 \times 0.9827&&\textcolor{#4257b2}{e^{-0.0175}\approx0.9827} \\
& = \$44.2215\\
\end{aligned}$$ 

Thus we have the present value of the exercise price $\text{PV(E)}$ as $\$44.215$

Now we will use the put parity equation in step 3 to determine the price of the call option:


The said equation can be rearranged as follows: 

$$\begin{aligned} 
  \text{C} &= \text{S + P} - \text{PV(E)} \\
& = \$48 + \$2.34 - \$44.2215\\
& = \$6.1185\\
\end{aligned}$$

Thus we have the value of C is $6.1185.
Therefore, the call option price with the same exercise price of $\$45$ is $\$6.1185$.
